questions.text: A 70-year-old female is posted for Total hip replacement surgery. She has been taking Amitriptyline for the past 25 years to help with the pain. What is the pre-operative order you will give regarding this medication ?
questions.correct_answer: B. Stop 3 weeks prior to surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Stop 3 weeks prior to surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:-
  • • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as Amitriptyline , should be stopped three weeks prior to surgery for several important reasons:
  • • Amitriptyline
  • • stopped three weeks prior
  • • Pharmacokinetics: TCAs have a relatively long half-life , meaning they persist in the body for an extended period after the last dose . By discontinuing TCAs three weeks before surgery, it allows adequate time for the drug and its active metabolites to be eliminated from the patient's system. This is essential to minimize the risk of drug interactions with anesthetics and other medications used during surgery.
  • • Pharmacokinetics:
  • • relatively long half-life
  • • extended period after the last dose
  • • eliminated
  • • minimize the risk of drug interactions
  • • anesthetics
  • • Anticholinergic Effects: TCAs have strong anticholinergic properties , which can lead to side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention , and increased heart rate . These effects can be exacerbated when TCAs are combined with anesthesia drugs , potentially resulting in cardiovascular and central nervous system complications during surgery.
  • • Anticholinergic Effects:
  • • strong anticholinergic properties
  • • side effects
  • • dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention
  • • increased heart rate
  • • anesthesia drugs
  • • cardiovascular and central nervous system
  • • Hypotension and Arrhythmias: TCAs can cause hypotension (low blood pressure) and arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) . These cardiovascular effects can be problematic during surgery, where maintaining stable blood pressure and heart rhythm is crucial for patient safety. Stopping TCAs well in advance reduces the likelihood of these complications.
  • • Hypotension and Arrhythmias:
  • • hypotension (low blood pressure)
  • • arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms)
  • • Serotonin Syndrome: In some cases, TCAs can interact with other drugs used during surgery to increase serotonin levels, potentially leading to serotonin syndrome —a serious and life-threatening condition characterized by symptoms such as agitation, confusion, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, dilated pupils, muscle rigidity, and even coma . By discontinuing TCAs early, the risk of serotonin syndrome is minimized .
  • • Serotonin Syndrome:
  • • interact with other drugs
  • • increase serotonin levels, potentially leading to serotonin syndrome
  • • serious
  • • life-threatening condition
  • • agitation, confusion, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, dilated pupils, muscle rigidity,
  • • even coma
  • • minimized
  • • Neurological Effects: TCAs can affect the central nervous system and may interact with anesthetic agents, potentially causing excessive sedation or adverse neurological effects during surgery.
  • • Neurological Effects:
  • • affect
  • • central nervous system
  • • excessive sedation
  • • adverse neurological effects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ All antipsychotic medications need to be continued peri-operatively EXCEPT

questions.text: The American Society of Anesthesiologists says that clopidogrel should be withheld for how many days before surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1 week

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:-
  • • The American Society of Anesthesiologists recommends withholding clopidogrel for typically 5 to 7 days before surgery .
  • • American Society of Anesthesiologists
  • • typically 5 to 7 days before surgery
  • • Here's why clopidogrel is temporarily stopped before surgery:
  • • Antiplatelet Effect: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medication that inhibits the aggregation of platelets , which are blood cells that play a crucial role in forming clots . By reducing platelet aggregation, clopidogrel helps prevent the formation of blood clots in arteries , reducing the risk of conditions like heart attacks and strokes . However, this antiplatelet effect can also increase the risk of bleeding during surgery. Risk of Bleeding: Surgery, especially procedures that involve incisions or manipulation of tissues , carries a risk of bleeding. When clopidogrel is continued close to the time of surgery, it can interfere with the normal blood clotting process , potentially leading to excessive bleeding during and after the operation. Time for Platelet Function to Normalize: Stopping clopidogrel for about a week before surgery allows the drug's effects on platelet function to diminish . Platelets have a lifespan of about 7 to 10 days, so withholding clopidogrel for this period allows for the turnover of the affected platelets with normal, non-inhibited platelets . Balancing Risks: The decision to stop clopidogrel and the specific timing may vary depending on the patient's individual circumstances , the type of surgery planned, and the underlying medical conditions. In some cases, the risk of stopping clopidogrel (i.e., increased risk of clot-related events) must be carefully weighed against the risk of bleeding during surgery

questions.text: What is the ideal time for giving pre-operative antibiotic to prevent surgical site infections?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:-
  • • Pre-operative Antibiotic should ideally be given 1 hour prior to surgery. This is because:
  • • Pre-operative Antibiotic should ideally be given 1 hour prior to surgery.
  • • Optimal Tissue Concentration: The main reason for administering antibiotics prior to surgery is to achieve peak antibiotic levels in the blood and tissues at the time of surgical incision . This ensures that there's a maximal concentration of the antibiotic in the tissues, where it's needed most , to effectively counteract potential sources of infection introduced during the procedure . Half-life and Pharmacokinetics: Different antibiotics have different half-lives and pharmacokinetics . Administering them about an hour before surgery allows sufficient time for the drug to be distributed throughout the body and achieve therapeutic levels at the surgical site. Tourniquet Consideration: If a tourniquet is being used during surgery (as is common in certain orthopedic procedures ), it's essential to administer the antibiotic before inflating the tourniquet. Once the tourniquet is inflated, blood flow to the limb is temporarily restricted , which could prevent the antibiotic from reaching the surgical site in effective concentrations .

questions.text: A child with symptoms of severe URTI is postponed for elective cochlear implant placement surgery. After how many days can he be taken up for the surgery?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:-
  • • Upper Respiratory Tract Infections (URTI) can increase the risk of perioperative respiratory complications , especially in pediatric patients . These complications can include bronchospasm, laryngospasm, postoperative desaturation, atelectasis, pneumonia, and prolonged recovery .
  • • Upper Respiratory Tract Infections (URTI)
  • • perioperative respiratory complications
  • • pediatric patients
  • • bronchospasm, laryngospasm, postoperative desaturation, atelectasis, pneumonia,
  • • prolonged recovery
  • • Two weeks is a commonly recommended waiting period to mitigate potential risks associated with performing elective surgery after an URTI, ensuring the safest possible environment for the pediatric patient because of these reasons :
  • • commonly recommended waiting period
  • • mitigate
  • • potential risks
  • • performing elective surgery
  • • Resolution of Inflammation: Even after the symptoms of an URTI subside, the inflammation in the respiratory tract can linger . Waiting for 2 weeks allows sufficient time for this inflammation to resolve , decreasing the risk of perioperative respiratory complications. Clearance of Secretions: Post-URTI, there may be an increase in respiratory secretions . These secretions can pose a risk during anesthesia and post-operatively . A 2-week period allows for these secretions to decrease to a more normal level . Immune System Recovery: After an infection, the body's immune system is in a recovery phase . Waiting ensures that the child's body is better prepared to handle the stress of surgery and the subsequent healing process . Reduced Viral Shedding: Even after symptoms resolve, a person can still shed the virus and be contagious. Waiting reduces the risk of transmitting the virus to healthcare workers and other patients.
  • • Resolution of Inflammation: Even after the symptoms of an URTI subside, the inflammation in the respiratory tract can linger . Waiting for 2 weeks allows sufficient time for this inflammation to resolve , decreasing the risk of perioperative respiratory complications.

questions.text: Lithium potentiates the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. How many days before administration of the muscle relaxant should lithium be stopped?
